Hey all.

I'm headed to Moho for the first time in this version with a small ISRU, orbital fuel tanker, a scan sat, a resource scanner and a surface rover/ scanner.  My question is:are radiators required for Moho orbital /surface operations?

Thanks in advance.

Edited January 6, 2016 by Aethon

49 minutes ago, Aethon said:

Hey all.

I'm headed to Moho for the first time in this version with a small ISRU, orbital fuel tanker, a scan sat, a resource scanner and a surface rover/ scanner.  My question is:are radiators required for Moho orbital /surface operations?

Thanks in advance.

If you're not doing anything that normally would require radiators-- i.e. you're not running any LV-N engines, or mining, or doing ISRU, etc.-- then you can get by without radiators, though I've heard that if you have a heatshield on your craft, it can slowly leak ablator if you don't have radiators to keep it cool.

However, if you have any heat generation at all, then you'll need more radiators than you otherwise would.

And-- this is very important-- make sure you use only the folding radiators, not the static radiator panels.  Reason:  The folding radiators automatically track the sun so that they stay edge-on to it, so they can radiate even when they're in full sunlight.  The static panels can't do this, so they could end up actually hurting you by absorbing more heat (from sunlight) than they radiate.  In any situation where solar heating is an issue, you want to use the sun-tracking panels.

(Also, just in case you're running an older version of KSP:  Before 1.0.5, there was a bug so that the folding radiators weren't actually helped by the sun-tracking; even though they looked like they were edge-on to the sun, they were still acting as if they were fixed in their initially-deployed position.  The bug was fixed in 1.0.5.  So make sure you're running the latest version!)

Moho's fairly close to the limit of what's tolerable without radiators, however.  If you're venturing significantly closer to the sun than Moho (for example, if you're running the New Horizons mod and are going to visit Moh, Moho, or Ernus), then you'll definitely need radiators.

Edited January 6, 2016 by Snark

3 hours ago, Aethon said:

I'm headed to Moho for the first time in this version with a small ISRU, orbital fuel tanker, a scan sat, a resource scanner and a surface rover/ scanner.  My question is:are radiators required for Moho orbital /surface operations?

At Moho, on the surface, anything that's rather heat-sensitive will show a bronze-to-orange temperature gauge.  This includes most science instruments, antenna, and EVA Kerbals.  However, that's just due to the ambient temperature there.  They won't get any hotter so after a while you get used to it.  So, as @Snark says, you don't need any radiators if your stuff on the ground doesn't need radiators back at Kerbin, but you can tell you're right on the verge of that.  Don't go any closer to the sun

It's a bit different for stuff that DOES need radiators back at Kerbin, such as nuclear engines and ISRU/drills.  Everything at Moho will soon achieve thermal equlilibrium at the ambient temperature, which is pretty warm.  This includes radiators you're not currently using because you're not running ISRU or nukes. Heat flows best, and thus radiators work best, when there's the biggest temperature difference between the radiators and the environment.  Because your radiators are already pretty warm due to ambient conditions, and because there's a fair amount of heat throughout the ship when it's just sitting there, you'll find you need a bit more radiator capacity at Moho than Kerbin to run heat-making stuff full-blast.  The radiators can't lose as much heat as quickly because ambient is higher, the radiators start out at the relatively high ambient temperature so can't take as much extra heat coming in without reach their capacity, and they have more heat coming in from other parts because every part is at the high ambient temperature.  So maybe having about 25% more "core heat xFer" than required would be a good idea.  It's not a LOT more than mormal but having at least some extra is a good idea.
